thread.title: Barbara Bedell: Gracie the pup will lead Monroe's CROP Walk
thread.title_full: Barbara Bedell: Gracie the pup will lead Monroe's CROP Walk

title: Barbara Bedell: Gracie the pup will lead Monroe's CROP Walk
text: 3:05 PM   3:05 PM » Social News The 19th Monroe CROP Hunger Walk Sunday, which hopes to attract 120 walkers and raise $10,000, will be led by Gracie, a friendly pup from Highland Mills. She has joined her owner, Paul Ellis Graham, on just about every CROP walk, and she’s proven to be a good leader. Last year there were 60 walkers, who raised about $8,000, said Fred Schuepfer, the walk’s coordinator from its beginning. “Gracie has been on the walk for many years,” said Schuepfer. “Naming her Grand Marshal seems long overdue for all the promoting she has done on behalf of the hungry, locally and in places around the world.” Twenty-five percent of the funds collected stay in the area and will benefit food pantries in Monroe, Woodbury, Chester and Washingtonville. The rest of the money will be pooled with community Hunger Walks in some 2,000 cities and towns nationwide, and be earmarked for communities around the world where people are starving. To help, call Schuepfer at 782-8386. Coming up - A lecture on the waters of Kilimanjaro will be given at 7 p.m Tuesday in Kaplan Hall at SUNY Orange in Newburgh. It will be presented by Dr. Matthew Bender, a specialist in East African environmental history. - A Tricky Tray Social will be held Saturday at the Infant Saviour Church in Pine Bush. It will be hosted by the Walker Valley Catholic Society. Doors open at 6 p.m. Calling is at 7. This and that - The recent social to benefit the Orange County Land Trust (469-0951) at the Newburgh Brewing Company was successful, raising around $400. - The Greater Newburgh Rotary, led by Mike Matsler, president, recently gave $1,000 to the Newburgh DARE Program through Rotarian Vincent Spampinato, who has been involved with the DARE program for years. - Miles of Hope Breast Cancer Foundation executive director Pari Forood received a check for $350 from John Guidice at the Newburgh Elks Lodge 247, during a recent social. - The Hudson Gateway Association of Realtors Foundation recently raised $15,000 at an inaugural Gala in New Rochelle to benefit local charities. The Foundation has long been involved with the Make a Wish Foundation of the Hudson Valley in which several of the recipients have lived in this area. The Association has properties throughout the region, including Orange, Sullivan, Ulster and Dutchess counties. Richard Haggerty is the HGAR CEO and Drew Kessler is the HGAR president. Barbara Bedell’s column appears daily. Reach her at 346-3125 or by email, bbedell@th-record.com. recordonline.com
